ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Most clients have difficulty tolerating the distress exposure therapy evokes.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Exposure therapy addresses the superficial symptoms of an anxiety disorder but does not target their root cause.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Exposure therapy works poorly for complex cases, such as when the client has multiple diagnoses.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Compared to other psychotherapies, exposure therapy leads to higher dropout rates.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Conducting exposure therapy sessions outside the office increases the risk of an unethical dual relationship with the client.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Exposure therapy is difficult to tailor to the needs of individual clients.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Compared to other psychotherapies, exposure therapy is associated with a less strong therapeutic relationship.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Asking the client to discuss traumatic memories in exposure therapy may retraumatize the client.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: It is unethical for therapists to purposely evoke distress in their clients.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Clients are at risk of decompensating (i.e., losing mental and/or behavioral control) during highly anxiety-provoking exposure therapy sessions.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Conducting exposure therapy sessions outside the office endangers the client's confidentiality.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Arousal reduction strategies, such as relaxation or controlled breathing, are often necessary for clients to tolerate the distress exposure therapy evokes.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Compared to other psychotherapies, exposure therapy places clients at a greater risk of harm.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Most clients perceive exposure therapy to be unacceptably aversive.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Exposure therapy often causes clients' anxiety symptoms to worsen.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Asking the client to discuss traumatic memories in exposure therapy may vicariously traumatize the therapist.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Clients may experience physical harm caused by their own anxiety (e.g., loss of consciousness) during highly anxiety-provoking exposure therapy sessions.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Having clients conduct exposures in their imagination is sufficient; facing feared stimuli in the real world is rarely necessary.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Exposure therapy is inhumane.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Most clients refuse to participate in exposure therapy.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Compared to other psychotherapies, exposure therapy increases the risk that the therapist will be sued for malpractice.
Notes: 0 = Disagree Strongly; 1 = Disagree; 2 = Unsure; 3 = Agree; 4 = Agree Strongly

ElementDescription: Total Score
